newsitem.title: GERMANY: German call money slips even as Buba plans drain.
newsitem.headline: German call money slips even as Buba plans drain.

text.p: German call money rates on Wednesday slipped below the 3.10 percent line for the first time in days, signalling smooth liquidity conditions even as the Bundesbank plans a considerable drain in funds.
"We are seeing more trades conducted at rates below 3.10 percent than we have in several days," one trader said halfway through Wednesday's session.
And while the bulk of trades was still being conducted at 3.10 percent, dealers said the day's range of 3.07/3.10 percent was clearly below Tuesday's 3.10/3.12 percent range.
But the slight dip in rates should not be interpreted as foreshadowing renewed hopes for a German rate cut, dealers said on the eve of the Bundesbank's policy setting council meeting.

Rather the moves were triggered by technical factors, dealers said, explaining that the so-called Tuesday float buoyed monthly reserve holdings, allowing dealers a bit more breathing room in today's trading.
"Reserve numbers are pretty good because of the float, and so the situation has become a bit more relaxed," a dealer said.
Banks held 41.7 billion marks on Tuesday, up from 39.8 billion marks held on Monday.
Average monthly holdings totalled 41.0 billion marks on Tuesday, down slightly form 41.1 billion marks a day earlier.
Dealers said it was still difficult to evaluate how the Bundesbank's announcement today that it would drain 9.1 billion marks from the system tomorrow would affect rates.
"We will have to see how this is offset by the transfer of Bundesbank profits to the government," a dealer explained.
Every year the Bundesbank awards a portion of its annual profits to the government which in turn uses the money to pare back debt. Some of these funds are then returned to the money market.
Economists said they see a smaller profit in 1996 than 1995's 10.928 billion mark result. Some 10.318 billion marks of that profit was sent to Bonn.
The Bundesbank will detail its 1996 results at a news conference beginning at 1200 GMT on Thursday.
On Tuesday banks' borrowings at the emergency Lombard borrowing facility were again negligible.
The Frankfurt Interbank Overnight Average (FIONA) was set at 3.12400 percent on Wednesday after 3.13033 percent on Tuesday.
